https://prez.dev/description.@value: Listing of standard nomenclature types (typus) and publication statuses that may characterize fossil, mineral or meteorite samples/specimens held in the Geological Survey of Western Australia's collections. These terms should only be applied to physical items, and are not applicable to derived results or data. This vocabulary includes terms for type specimens as recognized under several international nomenclature codes (see History Note for details). Taxonomic schemes applied to different classes of objects each have their own set of accepted types, and can define the same term differently, so care should be taken to use the correct nomenclature when referring to type specimens; to minimize confusion, individual terms have been labelled with a suffix indicating the relevant code. Note that multiple statuses can apply to a single specimen (e.g. by definition a type specimen will always be described-and-published).

A sample or specimen that has been mentioned or listed in a formal (peer-reviewed) scientific publication, but not imaged (drawn or photographed) or formally described. This term is only applicable to non-type samples or specimens.

A sample or specimen to which a name or identification and full description has been applied in a formal (peer-reviewed) publication. 'Described and published' can be interchangeable with 'figured' if a specimen is illustrated in the primary reference; illustration is common in primary descriptions, but is not a requirement, especially where large collections of specimens are being described together.

A sample or specimen that has been imaged (drawn or photographed) in a formal (peer-reviewed) scientific publication. Imaging may be in service of demonstrating the specimen's identity, preservation, interpretation, or any other purpose; these specimens are often conserved alongside type specimens due to their highly representative nature, and/or selection to illustrate particular or significant features. 'Figured' is partially interchangeable with 'described and published' and/or 'formally identified' in that specimen illustrations are essentially independent of whether a specimen is mentioned, formally identified and/or fully described within a publication.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The status of a specimen in relation to how it has been portrayed in the scientific literature (e.g. figured, cited)

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The status of a specimen in relation to how it has been portrayed in the scientific literature (e.g. figured, cited)
